December 22, 1985: Fiction
THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues
her adventures in the prehistoric world in a sequel to ''The Clan of the Cave Bear''
and ''The Valley of Horses.''
LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a
small American town.
TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $21.95.) Four hundred fifty
years of history in fictional form.
CONTACT, by Carl Sagan. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The commotion that
follows the reception of a signal from intelligent life beyond Earth.
SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Behind the scenes during the
production of a blockbuster television series.
THE POLAR EXPRESS, written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. (Houghton
Mifflin, $15.95.) A small boy's train ride to the North Pole on Christmas Eve and
the magical events that followed.
GALAPAGOS, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Seymour Lawrence/Delacorte, $16.95.)
Passengers on a Pacific cruise are mankind's sole survivors.
WORLD'S FAIR, by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $17.95.) A boy growing up
in New York City during the 1930's.
THE SECRETS OF HARRY BRIGHT, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $17.95.) A
detective searches for the meaning of his own son's death while investigating a
killing in the California desert.
SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $18.95.) Twenty-two tales of
contemporary horror.
THE CAT WHO WALKS THROUGH WALLS, by Robert A. Heinlein. (Putnam,
$17.95.)A comic look at a future in which mankind tries to control fate.
THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $16.95.) Family and friends
impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer.
WHAT'S BRED IN THE BONE, by Robertson Davies. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking,
$17.95.) The career of a Canadian painter who goes abroad to become an art
collector, forger and spy.
LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The heiress of a crime
lord takes on the heiress of a shipping tycoon.
THE VAMPIRE LESTAT, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $17.95.) Eerie carryings-on in a
December 22, 1985
Non-Fiction
YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.)
The story of the first man to fly faster than sound.
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with  William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler.
I NEVER PLAYED THE GAME, by Howard Cosell with Peter Bonventre. (Morrow,
$18.95.) A dour view of the sports world by the broadcaster.
ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Putnam,
$16.95.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband, father.
ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.)
The television reporter tells of Americans he's encountered.
DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine.(Bantam, $17.95.) In her 51st
year, the entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new
visions of the past and future.
HOUSE, by Tracy Kidder. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) An account of the
construction of a Greek Revival house in Massachusetts.
ANSEL ADAMS, by Ansel Adams with Mary Street Alinder. (New York Graphic
Society/Little, Brown, $50.) The profusely illustrated memoirs of the eminent
photographer.
SHOOT LOW, BOYS - THEY'RE RIDIN' SHETLAND PONIES, by Lewis Grizzard.
(Peachtree Publishers, $13.95.) A humorist looks for unsung Americans with ''true
grit.''
ONLY ONE WOOF, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) The true story,
illustrated by Peter Barrett, of how a Yorkshire sheepdog found his long-lost
brother.
''YOU CAN FOOL ALL OF THE PEOPLE ALL OF THE TIME,''  by Art Buchwald.
(Putnam, $16.95.) Humorous observations on the Reagan era by the syndicated
humorist..
MADE IN AMERICA, by Peter Ueberroth with Richard Levin and Amy Quinn.
(Morrow, $17.95.) The autobiography of the organizer of the 1984 Olympic Games
in Los Angeles.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse
and drawings.
CHARLES & DIANA, by Ralph G. Martin. (Putnam, $18.95.) A gossipy account of
the lives of the British royal couple.
